questions.text: A 32 year old female presented to the OPD with frequent heartburn with dysphagia since 8 months with occasional bitter taste in mouth with recent hoarseness of voice. Chest radiograph was done initially with no significant findings. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GERD Clinical features of GORD are dysphagia with heartburn , regurgitation which is more common in the night and due to frequent regurgitation the patient experiences bitter taste with vocal cords getting exposed to the acidic gastric contents leading to hoarseness .GERD Develops if the length of intraabdominal oesophagus < 2cm.

Highyeild:

Classical triad of GERD symptoms: retrosternal burning pain, epigastric pain, and regurgitation GERD can lead to complications such as esophageal ulcerations (5%), peptic strictures (4-20%), and Barrett's esophagus (8-20%) The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is important in preventing reflux; GERD is often associated with a hiatal hernia (most commonly type I or sliding hernia) Most common presentation of GERD: long-standing history of heartburn and a shorter history of regurgitation Diagnosis includes endoscopy to exclude other diseases and document peptic esophageal injury; important for those being considered for operative intervention.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. The females do not have complaints related to hypothyroidism like dry skin , fatigue etc. Option: C. No history of lump or swelling in the neck or history of addiction. Option: D. No sensation of obstruction and clear radiograph.

Extraedge:

Hiatal hernia is not necessary or sufficient for GERD diagnosis; its presence does not indicate the need for operative correction. Many people with hiatal hernias are asymptomatic and do not require treatment. GERD symptoms include heartburn (80%), regurgitation (54%), abdominal pain (29%), cough (27%), dysphagia for solids (23%), belching (15%), bloating (15%), aspiration (14%), and wheezing (7%). Manometry is useful for assessing the function of the esophageal body and LES.

questions.text: A 42 yr man presents with complaints of heartburn , difficulty in swallowing with occasional bitter taste. On asking he gave a history of progression and self-medication in the form of antacids which provided temporary relief. The best investigation to confirm the diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

24- hr pH monitoring 24- hr pH monitoring is the gold standard investigation for GERD. The Ph probe is placed 5cm proximal to gastroesophageal junction, if Ph <4 for 4% time in a 24 hour period indicates GERD.

Highyeild:

Gold standard for GERD diagnosis and quantification of acid reflux is the 24-hour pH test. The study provides information on total number of reflux episodes (pH < 4), longest episode of reflux, number of episodes lasting >5 minutes, and extent of reflux in upright and supine positions. DeMeester score is obtained using a formula that weighs each item's capacity to cause esophageal injury; score should be <14.7.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. A. Esophageal manometry is not useful in confirming the diagnosis as there is transient LOS relaxation and the function of LOS is preserved. Can be easily confused with esophageal motility disorder Option: B. Not a significant investigation in this. Option: D. It will not help to confirm the diagnosis is mild cases, in severe cases due to reflux oesophagitis or metaplastic change it can help to diagnose but not confirm.It is investigation of choice but not the best{gold standard}investigation for GERD.

Extraedge:

Esophagogram is used to evaluate GERD symptoms when considering surgery or when symptoms do not respond as expected; can characterize presence and size of hiatal hernia. Wireless method :Bravo24.

questions.text: In oesophageal motility disorder with elevated IRP{Integrated relaxation pressure};no normal peristalsis and spastic contraction ;DCI{Distal contractile index} >450mmhg/sqcm with >20% swallows is of the following type according to the Chicago classification?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type III achalasia Hierarchy diagnostic algorithm of oesophageal motility disorders according to the Chicago classification 4.0. The broad categories of 'disorders of oesophagogastric junction (OGJ) outflow' and 'disorders of oesophageal peristalsis' are differentiated by the integrated relax- ation pressure (IRP). FLIP, functional lumen imaging planimetry; IBP, intrabolus pressurisation; LOS, lower oesophageal sphincter, MRS, multiple rapid swallow; OGJOO, oesophagogastric outflow obstruction; POP, pan-oesophageal pressurisation; RDC, rapid drink challenge; TBO, timed barium oesophagram.

Highyeild:

Esophageal motility disorders: MC types are hypomotility and motility disorder. Achalasia: sphincter fails to relax causing constant tone with periods of relaxation. Both the muscle of esophagus and LES are affected. The primary pathology is destruction of nerves to LES, and the secondary pathology is degeneration of neuromuscular function of the body of the esophagus. Achalasia is a premalignant condition that can lead to squamous cell carcinoma. Triple A-syndrome or Allgrove disease: Achalasia, Alacrima and ACTH-resistant Adrenal insufficiency. The Chicago Classification of oesophageal motility v3.0. Achalasia and EGJ outflow obstruction Criteria Type I achalasia (classic achalasia) Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg), 100% failed peristalsis (DCI <100 mmHg-s-cm) Premature contractions with DCI values <450 mmHg-s-cm satisfy criteria for failed peristalsis Type II achalasia (with oesophageal compression) Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg), 100% failed peristalsis, panoesophageal pressurisation with 220% of swallows Contractions may be masked by oesophageal pressurisation and DCI should not be calculated Type III achalasia (spastic achalasia) Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg), no normal peristalsis, premature (spastic) contractions with DCI >450 mmHg-s-cm with 220% of swallows May be mixed with panoesophageal pressurisation EGJ outflow obstruction Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg), sufficient evidence of peristalsis such that criteria for types I-III achalasia are not met Major disorders of peristalsis (Not encountered in normal individuals) Absent contractility Normal median IRP, 100% failed peristalsis Achalasia should be considered when IRP values are borderline and when there is evidence of oesophageal pressurisation Premature contractions with DCI values <450 mmHg-s-cm meet criteria for failed peristalsis Distal oesophageal spasm Normal median IRP, 20% premature contractions with DCI >450 mmHg-s-cm. Some normal peristalsis may be present Hypercontractile oesophagus (jackhammer) At least two swallows with DCI >8000 mmHg-s-cm Hypercontractility may involve, or even be localised to, the LES Minor disorders of peristalsis (Characterised by contractile vigour and contraction pattern) Ineffective oesophageal motility (IEM) ≥50% ineffective swallows Ineffective swallows can be failed or weak (DCI <450 mmHg-s-cm) Multiple repetitive swallow assessment may be helpful in determining peristaltic reserve Fragmented peristalsis ≥50% fragmented contractions with DCI >450 mmHg-s-cm Normal oesophageal motility Not fulfilling any of the above classifications

questions.text: A 35 yr old male presented with difficulty on swallowing with on-off pain. Also experience food getting stuck. On extensive investigation he was confirmed with diffuse esophageal spasm, which of the following is not the feature?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

LOS function not preserved The function of lower esophageal sphincter is preserved in diffuse esophageal spasm..i.e. Lower esophageal sphincter is relaxed. The loss of LOS function occurs in achalasia

Highyeild:

Esophageal contractions: Repetitive, simultaneous, and high amplitude movements. Pathology: Motor abnormality in the lower two thirds of the esophagus. More common in women and often associated with multiple complaints. Clinical presentation: Chest pain and dysphagia (may mimic angina). Squeezing pressure in the chest that may radiate to the jaw, arms, and upper back. Symptoms aggravated by emotional stress. Diagnosis: Barium swallow shows corkscrew or rosary-bead esophagus, segmental spasm or pseudodiverticulosis appearance due to tertiary contractions, which indicate advanced disease.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Diffuse esophageal spasm is disorder of motility it is when the spasmodic premature contractions occur in the body of esophagus which are usually > 400mmHg of pressure on manometry , contraction of circular muscle occurs leading to corkscrew shaped esophagus on barium swallow. Option B C D: All other Options are features of DES.

Extraedge:

Clinical features in DES is similar to angina but ECG will be normal Investigation: Barium swallow : cork screw appearance or Rosary bead appearance because of spasm of circular muscles of esophagus. On manometry : Increase duration of contraction > 2.5 sec contraction, Increase Amplitude >120mmHg On High resolution Manometry: DCI{Distal Contractile Index}>450mmHg/sqcm, Integrated relaxation pressure is normal, Lower esophageal sphincter is relaxed. Management : Medical Management : Nitrates, Calcium Channel blockers , if patient does not respond,, Surgery--Myotomy

questions.text: Collis gastroplasty is the surgical modality used for which of the following GIT disorders?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

GERD Collis gastroplasty is done in GERD for lengthening of the esophagus. To achieve adequate length of esophagus a linear stapler is placed.

Highyeild:

Esophageal shortening may need Collis gastroplasty and partial fundoplication. Surgery reduces acid exposure but cannot restore normal levels due to poor esophageal clearance. Some surgeons choose to perform an esophageal lengthening procedure before fundoplication when encountering a shortened esophagus. This is done to reduce tension on the gastroesophageal junction and minimize the risk of failure due to postoperative hiatus hernia. The most commonly used technique for esophageal lengthening is Collis gastroplasty. Collis gastroplasty involves dividing the cardia and upper stomach with a stapler to create a gastric tube in continuity with the esophagus. After Collis gastroplasty, a fundoplication is constructed, typically with the highest suture placed on the native esophagus when constructing a Nissen fundoplication.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Barrett's esophagectomy Option: B. DES - myotomy Option: C. Esophageal perforation-partial esophagectomy

questions.text: A 40 year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. Three months ago, she was diagnosed with asthma after a 1-year history of a chronic cough and dyspnea with exertion. Her symptoms have improved since starting inhaled albuterol and beclomethasone, but she still coughs most nights when she is lying in bed. Over the past 2 weeks, she has also had occasional substernal chest pain. She does not smoke. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. She has a hoarse voice and frequently clears her throat during the examination. On examination of oral cavity, she also has dental caries. The lungs are clear on auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: D. Add a proton pump inhibitor
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Add a proton pump inhibitor PPIs are the treatment of choice for patients with peptic ulcer disease (PUD) or GERD because they effectively suppress gastric acid secretion. Empirical therapy with PPIs is only indicated in patients with dyspepsia and symptoms that strongly suggest GERD (heartburn and regurgitation). In all other patients with dyspepsia, such as this one, investigations to confirm the etiology (e.g., peptic ulcer disease, H. pylori infection, gastric malignancy) should precede therapy.

Highyeild:

Proton pump inhibitors ( PPIs ) are effective in managing erosive oesophagitis and acid-related symptoms, but may create a problem of overdiagnosis of GORD and overuse of PPIs due to the placebo effect . Endoscopic examination is useful for providing an anatomical assessment, screening for complications of GORD, and identifying alternative diagnoses. Oesophageal manometry and ambulatory pH recording (with or without impedance measurement) are recommended to establish the diagnosis and guide management for patients with atypical or persistent symptoms despite PPI therapy. High-resolution manometry ( HRM ) is a useful tool for detecting major oesophageal motility disorders, defining the location of the lower oesophageal sphincter (LOS), assessing the function and morphology of the LOS, and evaluating oesophageal body motility to tailor interventions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) may be considered to evaluate underlying cardiac pathologies. This patient's recurring chest pain, exertional dyspnea, and cough exacerbation when lying supine are possible symptoms of heart failure and lung edema. In some cases, severe mitral valve stenosis may lead to hoarseness due to recurrent laryngeal nerve damage by an enlarged left atrium. However, further signs and symptoms of heart failure such as peripheral pitting edema, increased jugular venous distention, nocturia, and tachycardia would be expected at this point. Moreover, except for obesity, this patient has no risk factors for heart disease (e.g., history of smoking, rheumatic fever, or hypertension), making a different etiology of her symptoms more likely. Option: B. Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist that is used in the management of moderate chronic asthma. Salmeterol would be a reasonable next step in the escalation of her asthma therapy because this patient currently uses a short-acting beta agonist and a corticosteroid inhaler. However, other comorbidities that potentially worsen asthma should be treated before escalating asthma therapy. Option: C. Oral prednisone is used to treat acute asthma exacerbations or severe, therapy-refractory chronic asthma. This patient does not present with acute dyspnea and wheezing, which makes an acute asthma exacerbation unlikely. In addition, her FEV1 of 78% of predicted indicates moderate asthma severity, which does not warrant an oral corticosteroid therapy.

Extraedge:

Before oesophageal pH recording, PPIs are usually stopped for 2 weeks. Wireless pH monitoring can increase the duration of recording to 96 hours and potentially increase the test sensitivity and diagnostic yield. A barium contrast study is useful in assessing surgical complications after antireflux surgery, but is not mandatory for ordinary and uncomplicated GORD patients.

questions.text: A 52 year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent retrosternal chest pain. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Endoscopy shows salmon pink mucosa extending 5 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy specimens from the distal esophagus show non ciliated columnar epithelium with numerous goblet cells. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.correct_answer: B. Esophageal exposure to gastric acid
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophageal exposure to gastric acid Esophageal mucosa is normally whitish pink and composed stratified squamous epithelium. Chronic exposure of the esophagus to gastric acid promotes transformation of the stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus to metaplastic columnar epithelium with goblet cells ( Barrett esophagus ). Barrett esophagus classically occurs in patients with GERD, which commonly presents with intermittent retrosternal pain, as seen in this patient. Adequate diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires histologic confirmation of intestinal metaplasia. There is increased risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus with barrets esophagus Diagnosis of Barret’s esophagus : Endoscopic biopsy from red velvety mucosa {check for goblet cells}

Highyeild:

Barrett's Esophagus is a condition where chronic injury to the distal squamous mucosa causes it to be replaced by metaplastic specialized epithelium. This condition is also known as columnar lined esophagus and is most commonly of the intestinal type. The main cause of Barrett's Esophagus is chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) . Symptoms include a long history of heartburn and other reflux symptoms, which are usually more severe and frequent than those experienced by most reflux patients. Barrett's Esophagus is a significant risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma. Diagnosis involves an endoscopic examination with random biopsies, and both an endoscopically visible segment of columnar lining and intestinal metaplasia showing goblet cells on biopsy are required.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Neoplastic proliferation of esophageal epithelium is seen in esophageal cancer. This patient is at increased risk to develop esophageal adenocarcinoma. However, he lacks typical features of an esophageal malignancy such as weight loss, dysphagia, and an ulcerative mass on endoscopy. Option: C. Atopic inflammation of the esophagus is seen in eosinophilic esophagitis, which is thought to be caused by an abnormal response of the immune system to an antigenic stimulus. Affected individuals commonly present with retrosternal pain, dysphagia to solids, and food impaction. Although this patient presents with retrosternal pain, biopsy would likely show numerous eosinophils within multiple layers of the esophagus rather than metaplastic changes. Option: D. Hypermotile esophageal contractions are seen in spastic disorders of the esophagus (e.g., nutcracker esophagus, diffuse esophageal spasms). Hypermotile esophagus may present with sudden, retrosternal chest pain and a distinctive pattern on barium swallow and manometry. Although this patient does have intermittent retrosternal pain, those conditions would not usually present with mucosal abnormalities.

Extraedge:

During endoscopy, a red velvety GI type mucosa may be observed between the pale squamous mucosa of the lower esophagus and the lush pink gastric mucosa. Goblet cells in the lining may contain acid mucin, typically sialomucin, and columnar cells contain neutral mucins that are PAS positive. Treatment for Barrett's Esophagus involves antireflux therapy, and surveillance endoscopy is necessary to detect dysplasia or early adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 30 year-old primigravid woman is brought to the emergency department after complaining of severe abdominal pain for 3 hours. She has had no prenatal care. There is no leakage of amniotic fluid. Pelvic examination shows a closed cervix and a uterus consistent in size with a 38-week gestation. Ultrasound shows a single live intrauterine fetus in a breech presentation consistent with a gestational age of approximately 37 weeks. The amniotic fluid index is 26 and the fetal heart rate is 92/min. The placenta is not detached. She is scheduled for an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate.The infant is delivered and APGAR score is noted to be 8 at 1 minute. The doctor soon notices cyanosis of the lips and oral mucosa, which does not resolve when the infant cries. The infant is foaming at the mouth and drooling.On insertion of NGT,the tube is coiled. He also has an intractable cough. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophageal atresia This patient has coughing spells, drooling, foaming at the mouth, and episodes of cyanosis , which are all indicative of esophageal atresia. Infants with esophageal atresia are usually unable to swallow during the prenatal period, which also explains the polyhydramnios in the vignette. It is associated with HPS, associated anomalies in 6–20% cases in HPS include -: Esophageal atresia, Hirschprung’s disease, ARM and malrotation XRAY SHOWING COILED NGT SEEN IN ESOPHAGEAL ATRESIA

Highyeild:

Clinical characteristics of EA may include the following: In infants who experience coughing or choking during their initial oral feeding, the possibility of EA diagnosis should be considered. The presence of polyhydramnios in the maternal medical history is often observed. Infants with atresia may regurgitate all of their first and subsequent feeds, with continuous drooling from their mouth. TEF may cause repeated episodes of coughing, choking, and cyanosis during feeding.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Choanal atresia presents immediately after birth and causes cyanotic attacks. However, cyanosis improves when the baby cries, as this involves breathing through the mouth rather than through the obliterated nasal passage. Option: C. Esophageal stricture appears as either a congenital or acquired disorder (e.g., after ingestion of batteries or caustic substances). Congenital esophageal stricture is usually not apparent at birth and only becomes apparent through dysphagia and regurgitation once the infant begins feeding with solids (i.e. around the weaning period). Additionally, it does not affect the airways and does not cause cyanotic attacks. Option: D. Achalasia is very rare in infants and occurs most commonly in middle-aged individuals. It causes dysphagia and regurgitation, which the infant here does not exhibit. Moreover, because it does not primarily affect the airways, it does not cause cyanosis.

Extraedge:

Esophageal atresia is sometimes a component of the VACTERL cluster of anomalies, which may include: V: Vertebral anomalies related to body segmentation A: Anal atresia C: Cardiovascular issues such as patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) or ventricular septal defects (VSD) TE: Tracheoesophageal fistula R: Renal abnormalities such as unilateral renal agenesis L: Limb anomalies such as radial ray hypoplasia

questions.text: A previously healthy 52 year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of progressively worsening substernal chest pain after meals. The pain occurs almost daily, is worst after eating spicy food or drinking coffee, and often wakes him up from sleep at night. He has not had any weight loss. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and he drinks 1 to 2 glasses of wine daily with dinner. Physical examination is unremarkable. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows erythema of the distal esophagus with two small mucosal erosions. Biopsy specimens obtained from the esophagus show no evidence of metaplasia. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophageal stricture Esophageal stricture is a common sequela of untreated GERD with esophagitis. Reflux esophagitis is the most common complication of GERD as the gastric acid causes inflammation, erosions, and ulcers of the esophageal mucosa. The inflamed esophageal mucosa heals via fibrosis, forming esophageal strictures. Initiation of appropriate therapy (e.g., PPI, lifestyle modifications) should be implemented to prevent this complication.

Highyeild:

Esophageal stricture can be caused by severe esophagitis or BE. If a patient has a stricture without Barrett’s esophagus, reflux esophagitis should be ruled out before ascribing the stricture to it. Normal acid exposure and no endoscopic or CT evidence of cancer may suggest a drug-induced chemical injury as the cause of the stricture. Dilation is usually effective in correcting drug-induced dysphagia. Patients with underlying esophagitis and a distal esophageal stricture secondary to gastroesophageal reflux can also develop drug-induced injuries. In this situation, a long, string-like stricture progressively develops and is often resistant to dilation. The incidence of this problem has decreased since proton pump inhibitor medication was introduced.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Esophageal adenocarcinoma is a rare complication of Barrett esophagus (BE) with dysplasia, which can develop in individuals with chronic untreated GERD. However, histological evidence of metaplastic columnar epithelium in esophageal biopsy specimens is required to make a diagnosis of BE, which is not seen here. Option: B. The most important risk factors for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma are cigarette smoking and chronic alcohol use, both of which are present in this patient. Additional risk factors include achalasia and caustic esophageal injury. However, this patient's GERD with reflux esophagitis does not increase the risk of him developing esophageal SCC GERD/Barrets esophagus increases risk of adenocarcinoma not SCC. Moreover, esophageal SCC typically occurs in the upper 2/3rd of the esophagus, whereas this patient has endoscopic evidence of distal esophageal disease. Option: C. Risk factors for laryngeal carcinoma include cigarette smoking and alcohol consumption, which are both present in this patient. However, although reflux of gastric acid into the larynx can cause chronic laryngitis and in severe cases, laryngeal and/or tracheal stenosis. Laryngeal carcinoma is not a known complication of untreated GERD with esophagitis.

questions.text: A 42 year-old obese woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of recurrent retrosternal chest pain that often wakes her up at night. Her ECG is normal. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Upper endoscopy shows hyperemia in the distal third of the esophagus. A biopsy specimen from this area shows non keratinized stratified squamous epithelium with hyperplasia of the basal cell layer and neutrophilic inflammatory infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dysfunction of gastroesophageal junction This patient's history of intermittent retrosternal chest pain that worsens at night, in conjunction with the hyperemia of the distal third of the esophagus and the biopsy showing non keratinized stratified squamous epithelium with hyperplasia of the basal cell layer and neutrophilic inflammatory infiltrates, is consistent with GERD. Dysfunction of the gastroesophageal junction allows stomach contents to flow back into the esophagus, causing inflammation of the esophageal epithelium. Risk factors for GERD include dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincte r due to anatomical disruption (e.g., due to hiatal hernia), decreased tension (e.g., due to smoking), and transient relaxation (e.g., due to obesity). Earliest pathophysiological abnormality indicator of GERD : Increased Transient LES relaxation.

Highyeild:

Classical triad of GERD symptoms: retrosternal burning pain, epigastric pain, and regurgitation GERD can lead to complications such as esophageal ulcerations (5%), peptic strictures (4-20%), and Barrett's esophagus (8-20%) The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is important in preventing reflux; GERD is often associated with a hiatal hernia (most commonly type I or sliding hernia) Most common presentation of GERD: long-standing history of heartburn and a shorter history of regurgitation Diagnosis includes endoscopy to exclude other diseases and document peptic esophageal injury; important for those being considered for operative intervention.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Increased lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone , as seen in achalasia, typically presents with dysphagia to both solids and liquids, although symptoms of esophageal reflux may also be present. Other features include retrosternal pain and weight loss. This patient does not present with symptoms of dysphagia, making achalasia an unlikely diagnosis. Option: B. Increased collagen production and fibrosis can be seen in CREST syndrome, which may be associated with esophageal dysmotility and reflux esophagitis. However, CREST syndrome is an uncommon condition and unlikely to manifest solely with reflux esophagitis; other features of CREST syndrome, such as calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia, are not seen in this patient. Option: C. Chronic gastrointestinal iron loss is seen in Plummer-Vinson syndrome. The syndrome manifests with a triad of dysphagia, upper esophageal webs, and iron deficiency anemia, none of which are seen in this patient.

GERD symptoms include heartburn (80%), regurgitation (54%), abdominal pain (29%), cough (27%), dysphagia for solids (23%), belching (15%), bloating (15%), aspiration (14%), and wheezing (7%). Manometry is useful for assessing the function of the esophageal body and LES.

questions.text: A 36 year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a burning sensation in his chest. The sensation is most prominent when he is lying in bed, but it is also present after eating heavy meals. He also states his breath has an unpleasant odor in the morning. He has not lost any weight during this period. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years and drinks 2–3 beers on weekend. His BMI is 32.9 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proton pump inhibitor Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are the first-line treatment for patients with uncomplicated GERD and no alarm symptoms (e.g., dysphagia, odynophagia, anemia, upper GI bleeding, weight loss, pneumonia, and/or hematemesis). Of all medications that are used in GERD, PPIs are associated with the greatest reduction in symptoms and relapse rates. In addition to dietary and lifestyle modifications, including avoiding late night meals, smoking cessation,avoid food which relax LES like chocolates, fried food, spicy food, citrus fruits,Tea/coffee, elevating the head of the bed while sleeping, and weight loss, this patient should be given a trial of PPIs.

Highyeild:

Proton pump inhibitors ( PPIs ) are effective in managing erosive oesophagitis and acid-related symptoms, but may create a problem of overdiagnosis of GORD and overuse of PPIs due to the placebo effect . Endoscopic examination is useful for providing an anatomical assessment, screening for complications of GORD, and identifying alternative diagnoses. Oesophageal manometry and ambulatory pH recording (with or without impedance measurement) are recommended to establish the diagnosis and guide management for patients with atypical or persistent symptoms despite PPI therapy. High-resolution manometry ( HRM ) is a useful tool for detecting major oesophageal motility disorders, defining the location of the lower oesophageal sphincter (LOS), assessing the function and morphology of the LOS, and evaluating oesophageal body motility to tailor interventions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Endoscopic examination of the esophagus to screen for Barrett's esophagus and adenocarcinoma is reserved for GERD patients with alarm symptoms (e.g., dysphagia, odynophagia, upper GI bleeding, anemia, weight loss, and/or chest pain), as well as for patients with chronic GERD despite medical treatment for 4–8 weeks and multiple risk factors for Barrett's esophagus (e.g., age > 50 years, central obesity). Patients with typical signs of GERD do not require endoscopy prior to initiating conservative treatment. Since this patient neither has alarm symptoms nor a history of chronic GERD, esophagogastroduodenoscopy is not indicated for the time being. PPI Screening for H. pylori infection via urea breath test is not indicated in patients with GERD alone because the prevalence of H. pylori infection among patients with GERD is not greater than in the general population. In fact, the prevalence of H. pylori is actually lower in patients with complicated or severe GERD. Screening for H. pylori infection is only indicated in patients with active peptic ulcer disease (PUD), a past history of PUD, atrophic gastritis, and/or gastric MALT lymphomas. Option: D. Barium swallow is the confirmatory test for esophageal diverticula (e.g., Zenker diverticulum), which may also present with halitosis and retrosternal discomfort, mimicking GERD. However, Zenker diverticulum is more common in men > 60 years of age and classically presents with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, and halitosis.

Extraedge:

Before oesophageal pH recording, PPIs are usually stopped for 2 weeks. Wireless pH monitoring can increase the duration of recording to 96 hours and potentially increase the test sensitivity and diagnostic yield. A barium contrast study is useful in assessing surgical complications after antireflux surgery, but is not mandatory for ordinary and uncomplicated GORD patients.

questions.text: A 4 5-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4 month history of upper abdominal pain that occurs immediately after eating. The pain is sharp, localized to the epigastrium, and doGGGes not radiate. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks 3 beers daily. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild upper abdominal tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastrointestinal bleeding Upper gastrointestinal tract hemorrhage is the most common complication in patients with peptic ulcer disease. This patient should undergo upper endoscopy to confirm the diagnosis (visual and tissue diagnosis) and assess the bleeding risk. Gastric ulcers with a visible blood vessel at the base are more likely to bleed due to erosion, which is why endoscopic interventions (e.g., clipping) are usually performed prophylactically and/or therapeutically.

Highyeild:

Peptic ulcers caused by H. pylori or NSAIDs Duodenal ulcers more common than gastric, but symptoms are similar Gastric ulcers can be malignant and mimic benign ulcers Gastric antisecretory agents and H. pylori eradication therapy are main treatments; elective surgery is rare Long-term complications of peptic ulcer surgery can be difficult to treat Common complications are perforation, bleeding, and stenosis Perforated peptic ulcers primarily treated with surgery, but some patients may be managed conservatively. pylori infection and NSAID consumption are key factors in peptic ulcer development Smoking increases risk of peptic ulcer and relapse after treatment

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Malignant transformation of gastric ulcers occurs in approx. 5–10% of patients with peptic ulcer disease (PUD). However, this is not the most common complication associated with PUD. Option: B. Gastric outlet obstruction (GOO) is an uncommon complication of peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Scarring of a chronic peptic ulcer or edema and inflammation of an acute peptic ulcer can cause GOO. However, advances in the medical management of PUD (i.e., treatment with proton pump inhibitors; antibiotics for H. pylori infection) have significantly decreased the incidence of GOO due to PUD. Option: D. A subhepatic abscess may develop secondary to a perforated peptic ulcer. Gastric ulcers are less likely to perforate compared to duodenal ulcers, making it very unlikely that this patient will develop a subhepatic abscess as a complication of his PUD.

Extraedge:

Peptic ulcer is most common cause of Non variceal upper G.I. bleed Gastritis is 2 nd most common cause of Non Variceal bleed

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: D. Watermelon stomach is seen in Dieulafoy’s lesion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Watermelon stomach is seen in Dieulafoy’s lesion Watermelon Stomach (Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia) and not in dieulafoy lesion. The parallel red stripes atop the mucosal folds of the distal stomach give this rare entity. Histologically, gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by dilated mucosal blood vessels that often contain thrombi, in the lamina propria.

Highyeild:

Watermelon Stomach (Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia) Rare entity characterized by parallel red stripes on the distal stomach mucosa Histologically, it is characterized by dilated mucosal blood vessels with thrombi and fibromuscular hyperplasia and hyalinization Resembles portal hypertensive gastropathy, but affects the distal stomach β-Blockers and nitrates are ineffective for treatment Most commonly affects elderly women with chronic GI blood loss requiring transfusion, and often associated with autoimmune connective tissue disorder or chronic liver disease Option A B C All other statements are correct

Treatment options: estrogen and progesterone, endoscopic treatment with Nd:YAG laser or argon plasma coagulator, antrectomy, and transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPSS) for patients with portal hypertension and antral vascular ectasia Antrectomy is effective but carries increased morbidity in elderly patients. Manangement of dieulafoy lesion : Endoscopic cauterization or embolization of affected vessels.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to several episodes of vomiting. The last episode of emesis contained blood 6 hours ago, he had a fatty meal and several alcoholic drinks. The patient's medical history is notable for alcohol abuse. He also has chronic dyspepsia, for which he was evaluated 3 days ago with upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and abdominal ultrasound. The ultrasound revealed an enlarged, hyperechoic liver and gallstones in the gallbladder, and the endoscopy found mild esophagitis and gastritis no varices noted. His vitals are normal. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The rectal examination shows no melena. Nasogastric suction returns normal stomach contents mixed with bright red blood. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's hemetemesis?

options.label: D
options.text: Mucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction

questions.correct_answer: D. Mucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction This patient with alcohol abuse, esophagitis, and gastritis now has acute, bright red hematemesis following multiple episodes of vomiting. This presentation is highly suggestive of a Mallory-Weiss tear (MWT) . MWT is characterized by longitudinal tears in the mucosa near the gastroesophageal junction, with bleeding due to injury to the submucosal arteries or veins. It typically occurs due to a sudden increase in intraabdominal pressure (eg, retching, blunt abdominal trauma).

Highyeild:

Mallory-Weiss tear Longitudinal tear at the GOJ caused by repetitive and strenuous vomiting. Lesions can occur without causing bleeding. When it causes haematemesis, the lesion may be difficult to see as it is just below the GOJ and hard to spot for inexperienced endoscopists. Sometimes these lesions continue to bleed and need surgery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A :Esophageal rupture can be caused by severe retching ( Boerhaave syndrome ), penetrating trauma, or as a complication of endoscopy. It is characterized by acute chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and often a left-sided pleural effusion. Option B : When esophageal rupture occurs due to endoscopy, it is usually apparent shortly after the procedure. Option C: Hemobilia (bleeding in the biliary tree) is an uncommon cause of upper GI hemorrhage. It is typically seen following abdominal trauma or surgery. Endoscopy without manipulation of the biliary system would not cause hemobilia. Most common vessel implicated in bleed is Left gastric artery.

Extraedge:

Persistent bleeding in Mallory Weiss Syndrome can be managed through different methods, including: Endoscopic electrocoagulation or endoscopic therapy with injection Angiographic embolization Surgery, which involves laparotomy and high gastrotomy with oversewing of the linear tear, only if the above methods fail.

questions.text: A 40year-old man has sudden onset of hematemesis after a weekend in which he consumed large amounts of alcohol. The bleeding stops, but he has another episode under similar circumstances 15 days later. Upper gastroesophageal endoscopy shows longitudinal tears at the gastroesophageal junction. What is the most likely mechanism to cause his hematemesis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vomiting Mallory-Weiss syndrome with esophageal tears results from severe vomiting. Most cases occur in the context of alcohol abuse. The bleeding is usually not as life-threatening as varices.

Highyeild:

Mallory-Weiss syndrome Causes: Mallory-Weiss tears occur due to forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining. Forceful contraction of abdominal wall against an unrelaxed cardia causes mucosal laceration of proximal cardia due to an increase in intragastric pressure. Tear is partial thickness, extending through the mucosa and submucosa , resulting in disruption of gastric mucosa high on the lesser curve at cardia ( just below GE junction). Clinical Features: Common in alcoholic patients after a period of intense retching and vomiting after binge drinking. Cause of up to 15% of all severe upper GI bleeds . Arterial bleeding (usually from left gastric artery), usually painless and rarely associated with massive bleeding. Overall mortality rate is 3-4% , with the greatest risk for massive hemorrhage in alcoholic patients with preexisting portal hypertension. Diagnosis: Usually diagnosed by history. Endoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A : Absent myenteric ganglia occur with achalasia. Option B : Herpes simplex virus infection causes ulcerations that are usually superficial and cause pain, but do not bleed significantly. Option C: Portal hypertension leads to dilation of esophageal submucosal veins, which can bleed profusely; in this case, the patient’s age argues against the presence of cirrhosis from alcohol abuse. Most common vessel implicated in bleed is Left gastric artery.

Extraedge:

Supportive therapy is often all that is necessary because 90% of bleeding episodes are self-limited, and the mucosa often heals within 72 hours. Persistent bleeding is managed by endoscopic electrocoagulation or endoscopic therapy with injection , angiographic embolization, or surgery (laparotomy and high gastrotomy with oversewing of the linear tear) if above maneuvers fail. Recurrent bleeding from a Mallory-Weiss tear is uncommon. Note: A Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is contraindicated in Mallory-Weiss syndrome as it will not stop bleeding due to arterial pressure.

questions.text: The Gold standard to diagnose Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

24 hrs pH monitoring 24-hour pH recording is the ‘gold standard’ for diagnosis of GORD Length and pressure of the LOS are important A small pH probe is passed into the distal oesophagus and positioned 5 cm above the upper margin of the LOS, as defined by manometry. The probe is connected to a miniature digital recorder that is worn on a belt and allows most normal activities. Patients mark symptomatic events such as heartburn. A 24-hour recording period is usual, and the pH record is analysed by an automated computer program. An oesophageal pH <4 at the level of the pH electrode is conventionally considered the cut-off value and, in most oesophageal laboratories, the total time when pH is <4 for> 4% time in a 24-hour period . Patterns of refluxand the correlation between symptoms and oesophageal pH <4 can be calculated. Most laboratories use a scoring system (Johnson–DeMeester) to create a numerical value, above which reflux is considered pathological.

Highyeild:

Gold standard for GERD diagnosis and quantification of acid reflux is the 24-hour pH test. The study provides information on total number of reflux episodes (pH < 4), longest episode of reflux, number of episodes lasting >5 minutes, and extent of reflux in upright and supine positions. DeMeester score is obtained using a formula that weighs each item's capacity to cause esophageal injury; score should be <14.7.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Barium radiology is, however, inaccurate in the diagnosis of gastro-oesophageal reflux, unless reflux is gross, and should not be used for this purpose. Plain radiographs will show some foreign bodies. Wireless method for 24 hr pH monitoring is Bravo24. Option B: IOC for GERD is Endoscopy, 24 hours pH monitoring is done if Endoscopy is inconclusive. Option D: Esophageal manometry is done in achalasia

Extraedge:

Esophagogram is used to evaluate GERD symptoms when considering surgery or when symptoms do not respond as expected; can characterize presence and size of hiatal hernia.

questions.text: A 47 years old alcoholic patient presented to the ER after vigorous vomiting and later had an episode hemetemesis. On endoscopy there are no esophageal varices but a longitudinal tear in esophagus is noted. The patient is suffering from:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mallory-Weiss syndrome In Mallory–Weiss syndrome, vigorous vomiting produces a longitudinal{vertical} split in the gastric mucosa, immediately below the squamocolumnar junction at the cardia.{at GE junction} In only 10% is the tear in the oesophagus. The condition presents with haematemesis. Usually, the bleeding is not severe, but endoscopic injection therapy may be required for the occasional, severe case.Surgery is rarely required.

Highyeild:

Mallory-Weiss syndrome Causes: Mallory-Weiss tears occur due to forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining. Forceful contraction of abdominal wall against an unrelaxed cardia causes mucosal laceration of proximal cardia due to an increase in intragastric pressure. Tear is partial thickness, extending through the mucosa and submucosa , resulting in disruption of gastric mucosa high on the lesser curve at cardia ( just below GE junction). Clinical Features: Common in alcoholic patients after a period of intense retching and vomiting after binge drinking. Cause of up to 15% of all severe upper GI bleeds . Arterial bleeding (usually from left gastric artery), usually painless and rarely associated with massive bleeding. Overall mortality rate is 3-4% , with the greatest risk for massive hemorrhage in alcoholic patients with preexisting portal hypertension

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. A: There are two other injuries to the oesophagus that lie within the spectrum of the mucosal tear of Mallory–Weiss and the full-thickness tear of Boerhaave. Intramural rupture produces a dissection within the oesophageal wall that causes severe chest pain, often with odynophagia. It is best diagnosed by contrast radiology. Intramural haematoma is seen most often in elderly patients on anticoagulants or patients with coagulation disorders, and usually follows an episode of vomiting. Option. C: BAROTRAUMA (spontaneous perforation, Boerhaave’s syndrome): This occurs classically when a person vomits against a closed glottis. The pressure in the oesophagus increases rapidly, and the oesophagus bursts at its weakest point in the lower third, sending a stream of material into the mediastinum and often the pleural cavity as well. Option. D: Spontaneous perforation also called as Boerhaave’s syndrome is the most serious type of perforation because of the large volume of material that is released under pressure. This causes rapid chemical irritation in the mediastinum and pleura followed by infection if untreated. Barotrauma has also been described in relation to other pressure events when the patient strains against a closed glottis (e.g. defecation, labour, weight-lifting).

Extraedge:

Supportive therapy is often all that is necessary because 90% of bleeding episodes are self-limited, and the mucosa often heals within 72 hours. Persistent bleeding is managed by endoscopic electrocoagulation or endoscopic therapy with injection , angiographic embolization, or surgery (laparotomy and high gastrotomy with oversewing of the linear tear) if above maneuvers fail. Recurrent bleeding from a Mallory-Weiss tear is uncommon. Note: A Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is contraindicated in Mallory-Weiss syndrome as it will not stop bleeding due to arterial pressure.

questions.text: Most common Symptom and Most common type of Ca Oesophagus respectively are:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dysphagia & Squamous cell carcinoma Earliest feature in esophageal cancer is Progressive dysphagia {Difficulty to swallow Solids> Liquids },weightloss IOC is Endoscopic Biopsy. Carcinoma of the Oesophagus: Squamous cell usually affects the upper two-thirds; adenocarcinoma usually affects the lower third

Highyeild:

Esophageal cancer is the 8th most common cancer and the 6th most common cause of cancer death worldwide. Squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma are the most common types of esophageal cancer. The incidence of esophageal cancer is higher in areas of high incidence than in the rest of the world. Aetiological factors vary between the two main types of esophageal cancer. Genetic predisposition may be important in the pathogenesis of esophageal squamous cell cancer. Dietary and environmental factors are important in the development of squamous cell carcinoma. Patients with other aerodigestive malignancies are at particularly high risk. The rise in incidence of adenocarcinoma coincides with the increase in obesity, GORD, and Barrett’s esophagus in Western populations

Squamous cell and adenocarcinoma develop from dysplastic mucosa Adenocarcinomas are mostly mucin producing with intestinal-type features Squamous cell cancers found in middle and upper oesophagus, adenocarcinoma in lower oesophagus and OGJ Lymph node metastasis can involve cervical area, mediastinum, and perigastric/coeliac axis Distant haematogenous spread can occur to non-regional lymph nodes, lungs, liver, brain, and bones Progressive dysphagia is the most common symptom Early symptoms may include mild hold-up sensation, anorexia, weight loss, odynophagia, and regurgitation symptoms Hoarseness Choking and cough Blood loss is less common for squamous cell cancer than adenocarcinoma
